block.p: CENTRAL PARK Making Fragrant Candles At the Smells' Source

If you wonder how candles are made or if natural scents have healing powers, the Mother's Day weekend workshops in Central Park will have answers. The workshops, put on by the Central Park Conservancy, are aimed at children 6 and up.

In ''Candle Creations'' visitors can make candles that have been inspired by the flowers of Central Park. In ''Floral Fragrances'' educators will discuss natural elements in the park that carry their own distinctive fragrances and the scents' supposed healing qualities. You can make a scented sachet.

SNUG HARBOR Terra Cotta Soldiers At Chinese Cultural Show

When China's first emperor died in 210 B.C., a terra cotta army surrounded his tomb to protect him in the afterlife. Some of those figures, from Xian, are featured in a show on ancient Chinese arts and sciences, which opens on Friday at the Staten Island Botanical Garden. More than 300 objects, including porcelain and bronze, will be displayed, and 13 artisans from China will demonstrate traditional arts. They will include papermaking and printing, silk reeling from cocoons, calligraphy and painting, brocade and embroidery, batik dyeing and eggshell paintings.

Ancient arts and sciences from China Friday through Oct. 1; Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Staten Island Botanical Garden, 1000 Richmond Terrace, near Snug Harbor Road; entrance to both the exhibition and the New York Chinese Scholar's Garden: $7.50; children 12 and under, students and people over 65, $5; (718) 273-8200.
PROSPECT HEIGHTS Register That Old Jug For Appraisal by Experts

Collectors of anything, from paperweights to pillboxes, Americana or jewelry -- or those who wonder how such objects are appraised -- are welcome to ''Collecting Marvels,'' this Saturday's appraisal day at the Brooklyn Museum of Art.

There will be onstage appraisals by experts from the William Doyle Galleries in New York, like David Gallager (shown at right), an American furniture and decorations specialist. An afternoon of appraisals will be accompanied by live Dixieland music, and Kevin Stayton, chairman of decorative arts at the museum, will deliver a lecture on collecting and value.

''Collecting Marvels,'' Saturday 1 p.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway (at Washington Avenue); $10; students and people over 65, $7; advance registration required to have an object appraised: (718) 638-5000, ext. 931.

DOUBLE BACH -- The Grace Choral Society of Brooklyn, which has more than 40 singers, is celebrating its 25th anniversary (and observing the 250th anniversary of Bach's death) with two Bach cantatas, No. 4 and 150, accompanied by a small orchestra; today 4 p.m.; Grace Church, 254 Hicks Street, near Joralemon Street, Brooklyn Heights; $15; students and people over 65, $6; children 12 and under free; (718) 707-1411.

CIRCLES OF HEALING -- Spiderwoman Theater, a Native American women's theater company, is celebrating its 25th anniversary with ''Persistence of Memory,'' a story of circles of healing that uses storytelling and video; Friday and Saturday 8 p.m.; American Indian Community House, 404 Lafayette Street, near East Fourth Street; suggested donation $10; (212) 598-0100.

WORKING WOMEN -- ''Sisterhood and Solidarity'' is the title of Connie Kopelov's walking tour of Union Square, where women struggled for jobs, unions, voting rights and an end to sweatshops; today 1 p.m.; meet at Amalgamated Bank, 15th Street and Union Square West; $10; (212) 673-4429.
